segments.source_content: An awesome interactive article showing that itâ€™s surprisingly hard to persist UI state to the query string in a React Server Component world and yet give immediate user feedback. Updating the URL triggers a server round-trip. The new `useOptimistic` hook solves this problem nicely. This also shows a nice use-case for CSS `:has()`, to avoid hoisting the `startTransition` pending state.

translations.fr: Un article interactif gÃ©nial montrant qu'il est Ã©tonnamment difficile de persister l'Ã©tat de l'UI dans la chaÃ®ne de requÃªte dans un monde de React Server Components tout en fournissant un retour utilisateur immÃ©diat. La mise Ã  jour de l'URL dÃ©clenche un aller-retour serveur. Le nouveau hook `useOptimistic` rÃ©sout ce problÃ¨me Ã©lÃ©gamment. Cela montre aussi un bon cas d'utilisation pour le CSS `:has()`, pour Ã©viter de remonter l'Ã©tat d'attente de `startTransition`.
translations.en: Un article interactif gÃ©nial montrant qu'il est Ã©tonnamment difficile de persister l'Ã©tat de l'UI dans la chaÃ®ne de requÃªte dans un monde de React Server Components tout en fournissant un retour utilisateur immÃ©diat. La mise Ã  jour de l'URL dÃ©clenche un aller-retour serveur. Le nouveau hook `useOptimistic` rÃ©sout ce problÃ¨me Ã©lÃ©gamment. Cela montre aussi un bon cas d'utilisation pour le CSS `:has()`, pour Ã©viter de remonter l'Ã©tat d'attente de `startTransition`.

segments.source_content: TIL about [Vinxi](https://vinxi.vercel.app/), a toolbox built on top of Vite and Nitro enabling you to easily create your own meta-framework, with support, SSR, routing conventions, server functions and everything. Solid Start uses it behind the hood, but itâ€™s a framework-agnostic SDK. Apparently, [TanStack Start will use it too](https://twitter.com/sebastienlorber/status/1762809340719780080)! This article explains how to use it with React.

translations.fr: Aujourd'hui, j'ai dÃ©couvert [Vinxi](https://vinxi.vercel.app/), une boÃ®te Ã  outils basÃ©e sur Vite et Nitro vous permettant de crÃ©er facilement votre propre mÃ©tadramework, avec support SSR, conventions de routage, fonctions serveur et plus encore. Solid Start l'utilise en coulisses, mais c'est un SDK agnostique des frameworks. Apparemment, [TanStack Start l'utilisera aussi](https://twitter.com/sebastienlorber/status/1762809340719780080) ! Cet article explique comment l'utiliser avec React.
translations.en: J'ai dÃ©couvert aujourd'hui [Vinxi](https://vinxi.vercel.app/), une boÃ®te Ã  outils basÃ©e sur Vite et Nitro vous permettant de crÃ©er facilement votre propre mÃ©ta-framework, avec support SSR, conventions de routage, fonctions serveur et bien plus. Solid Start l'utilise en arriÃ¨re-plan, mais c'est un SDK agnostique des frameworks. Apparemment, [TanStack Start l'utilisera aussi](https://twitter.com/sebastienlorber/status/1762809340719780080) ! Cet article explique comment l'utiliser avec React.

segments.source_content:
- ğŸ’¸ [Explore how to buildÂ a feature-rich PDF Viewer in React with Apryse's rendering engine. Customize UI, scroll, zoom, and search with annotations.](https://apryse.com/blog/build-custom-react-pdf-viewer?utm_source=thisweekinreact2&utm_medium=email&utm_campaign=newsletter2)
- ğŸ“œ [Avoiding Hydration Mismatches with useSyncExternalStore](https://tkdodo.eu/blog/avoiding-hydration-mismatches-with-use-sync-external-store): Another great article from Dominik explaining how `useSyncExternalStore` and its 2 client/server snapshot callbacks can help prevent hydration mismatches. It can be a better alternative to useEffect for many use-cases, including rendering localized dates, or creating a client-only wrapper component.
- ğŸ“œ [Exploring Next.js Forms with Server Actions](https://www.robinwieruch.de/next-forms/): A very comprehensive step-by-step tutorial on using the new React/Next.js form primitives without any abstractions, and all the little mistakes you might make along the way.
- ğŸ“œ [No Outer margin](https://kyleshevlin.com/no-outer-margin/): Gives good reasons to not apply margins inside your component root, but instead let the parent component handle the layout. Margins are the first thing that come to mind, but there are also other CSS rules that break component encapsulation. I recovered a great deleted article for you on that matter: [Layout-isolated components](https://web.archive.org/web/20201024040746/https://visly.app/blog/layout-isolated-components).
- ğŸ“œ [Vjeux - 12 Years at Meta](https://blog.vjeux.com/2024/project/12-years-at-meta.html): If you are a new React developer, you may not have heard of Christopher Chedeau, but heâ€™s one of the most impactful member of our community. A few things he created or significantly contributed to: React, React Native, Yoga, CSS-in-JS, Prettier, Excalidraw, Docusaurus, GraphQLâ€¦
- ğŸ“œ [Learning Four Key Primitives In Solid](https://www.brenelz.com/posts/learning-four-key-primitives-in-solid/): Donâ€™t be mislead by the title, itâ€™s a great article for React devs, comparing Solid vs React, Next.js and Remix on 4 interesting topics. TIL that Next.js RSC components would waterfall by default unless you use a preloading function.
- ğŸ“œ [Handle both JSON and FormData in Remix](https://www.jacobparis.com/content/conform-json-formdata): Jacob explains the tradeoffs of using form inputs vs creating a FormData or JSON payload manually on an event handler. Shows how to create an Remix abstraction using Zod and Conform that can conveniently accept both JSON and FormData paylods.
- ğŸ“œ [Introducing Waku Land](https://interbolt.org/blog/waku-land/): A live deployment of every Waku examples.
- ğŸ“œ [Where to host your Remix app in 2024](https://www.jacobparis.com/content/where-to-host-remix?ref=twitter): Updated on 25 Feb.
- ğŸ“œ [HTMX vs React - A Complete Comparison](https://semaphoreci.com/blog/htmx-react): The article suggests to use React for rich web experiences, and use HTMX for pages with simpler interactivity.
- ğŸ“œ [Next.js vs. Remix - A Developer's Dilemma](https://blog.saeloun.com/2024/02/21/next.js-vs-remix/)
- ğŸ“œ [Compiler Theory and Reactivity](https://www.recompiled.dev/blog/ssa/): Sathya works on React Forget and explains a compiler theory pass they use called Static Single Assignment form. I have to admit Iâ€™m a bit lost here ğŸ˜…. His previous post on [Alias analysis](https://www.recompiled.dev/blog/alias-analysis/) is easier to understand.
- ğŸ“œ [How to Style Active Links in Next.js App Router](https://spacejelly.dev/posts/how-to-style-active-links-in-next-js-app-router)
- ğŸ“œ [Add Dynamic Sitemap to Next.js Website Using Pages or App Directory](https://claritydev.net/blog/nextjs-dynamic-sitemap-pages-app-directory)
- ğŸ“¦ [@react-three/uikit - Build performant 3D user interfaces using react-three/fiber and yoga](https://github.com/pmndrs/uikit): New Poimandres collective package preview with an impressive ğŸ¦ [demo](https://twitter.com/0xca0a/status/1762069894932160943)
- ğŸ¥ [Ryan Toronto - Asset loading in React 19](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=dxWLp-8mXes): Explains a quite unknown but exciting upcoming React feature that lets you load assets (here CSS) of the next page before completing the navigation transition.
- ğŸ¥ [Jack Herrington - React Hook Form & React 19 Form Actions, The Right Way](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VLk45JBe8L8)
- ğŸ¥ [Fireship - They made React great again? (React Labs)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=4k6Xgjqkad4)
- ğŸ¥ [Fireship - This UI component library is mind-blowing (Aceternity Components)](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RPa3_AD1_Vs)
- ğŸ™ï¸ [PodRocket -StyleX with Naman Goel](https://podrocket.logrocket.com/stylex-naman-goel)

segments.source_content: This section is now co-authored with [Benedikt](https://twitter.com/bndkt). Feel free to send us your comments by email or on [Twitter](https://twitter.com/bndkt)!

translations.fr: Cette section est dÃ©sormais co-Ã©crite avec [Benedikt](https://twitter.com/bndkt). N'hÃ©sitez pas Ã  nous envoyer vos commentaires par email ou sur [Twitter](https://twitter.com/bndkt) !
translations.en: Cette section est dÃ©sormais co-Ã©crite avec [Benedikt](https://twitter.com/bndkt). N'hÃ©sitez pas Ã  nous envoyer vos commentaires par email ou sur [Twitter](https://twitter.com/bndkt) !

segments.source_content: This past week, we all enjoyed a brief respite from major headline React Native news (or did I miss something, in this case [@me](https://twitter.com/bndkt)). Perhaps that's a welcome change, especially after the whirlwind of events like Expo 50, visionOS, the State of React Native, react-strict-dom, and more. However, this doesn't mean the React Native world has come to a halt. Thereâ€™s been a lot of little announcements that give us a glimpse in the near future of React Native. The first release candidates for [RN 0.74](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/ee2bc59dfe4579cad3b7f0b5de667a89fcac8710/CHANGELOG.md#0740-rc0) were released. They contain a lot of improvements as well as some deprecations and breaking changes, but from the first glance nothing major that makes me worried about upgrading effort. Most notably, bridgeless mode becomes the new default with 0.74 (but only when New Arch is enabled). Bridgeless mode is the third pillar of the New Arch, after the already introduced TurboModules and new renderer (Fabric). Speaking of New Arch and defaults, a [PR](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/pull/43135) was merged thatâ€™ll make the New Arch the default beginning with RN 0.75 (it will still be possible to opt out though). Also, the RFC with the [React Native Frameworks](https://github.com/react-native-community/discussions-and-proposals/blob/main/proposals/0759-react-native-frameworks.md) definition has been merged, laying out the responsibilities of RN vs frameworks on top of RN.

translations.fr: Cette semaine, nous avons tous bÃ©nÃ©ficiÃ© d'une brÃ¨ve accalmie concernant les grandes nouvelles de React Native (ou ai-je manquÃ© quelque chose, dans ce cas [@moi](https://twitter.com/bndkt)). C'est peut-Ãªtre un changement bienvenu, surtout aprÃ¨s la tourmente des Ã©vÃ©nements comme Expo 50, visionOS, l'Ã‰tat de React Native, react-strict-dom, et plus encore. Cependant, cela ne signifie pas que l'Ã©cosystÃ¨me React Native s'est arrÃªtÃ©. De nombreuses petites annonces nous donnent un aperÃ§u du futur proche de React Native. Les premiÃ¨res versions candidates pour [RN 0.74](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/ee2bc59dfe4579cad3b7f0b5de667a89fcac8710/CHANGELOG.md#0740-rc0) ont Ã©tÃ© publiÃ©es. Elles contiennent de nombreuses amÃ©liorations ainsi que des dÃ©prÃ©ciations et des changements cassants, mais Ã  premiÃ¨re vue rien de majeur qui m'inquiÃ¨te quant Ã  l'effort de mise Ã  niveau. Plus notablement, le mode bridgeless devient le nouveau comportement par dÃ©faut avec la 0.74 (mais uniquement lorsque la New Arch est activÃ©e). Le mode bridgeless est le troisiÃ¨me pilier de la New Arch, aprÃ¨s les TurboModules dÃ©jÃ  introduits et le nouveau moteur de rendu (Fabric). En parlant de New Arch et des valeurs par dÃ©faut, une [PR](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/pull/43135) a Ã©tÃ© fusionnÃ©e qui fera de la New Arch le comportement par dÃ©faut Ã  partir de RN 0.75 (il sera toujours possible de s'en dÃ©sengager). De plus, la RFC dÃ©finissant les [React Native Frameworks](https://github.com/react-native-community/discussions-and-proposals/blob/main/proposals/0759-react-native-frameworks.md) a Ã©tÃ© fusionnÃ©e, dÃ©taillant les responsabilitÃ©s de RN par rapport aux frameworks construits sur RN.
translations.en: Cette semaine derniÃ¨re, nous avons tous apprÃ©ciÃ© une pause bienvenue concernant les grandes actualitÃ©s React Native (ou ai-je ratÃ© quelque chose ? Dans ce cas [@me](https://twitter.com/bndkt)). Peut-Ãªtre un changement rafraÃ®chissant, surtout aprÃ¨s la succession d'Ã©vÃ©nements comme Expo 50, visionOS, l'Ã‰tat de React Native, react-strict-dom, et plus encore. Cependant, cela ne signifie pas que l'Ã©cosystÃ¨me React Native s'est arrÃªtÃ©. De nombreuses petites annonces nous donnent un aperÃ§u du futur proche de React Native. Les premiÃ¨res versions candidates pour [RN 0.74](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/blob/ee2bc59dfe4579cad3b7f0b5de667a89fcac8710/CHANGELOG.md#0740-rc0) ont Ã©tÃ© publiÃ©es. Elles contiennent de nombreuses amÃ©liorations ainsi que des dÃ©prÃ©ciations et changements cassants, mais Ã  premiÃ¨re vue rien de majeur qui inquiÃ¨te concernant l'effort de mise Ã  jour. Plus notablement, le mode "bridgeless" devient le nouveau comportement par dÃ©faut avec la 0.74 (mais uniquement lorsque la New Arch est activÃ©e). Le mode bridgeless est le troisiÃ¨me pilier de la New Arch, aprÃ¨s les TurboModules dÃ©jÃ  introduits et le nouveau moteur de rendu (Fabric). En parlant de New Arch et des valeurs par dÃ©faut, une [PR](https://github.com/facebook/react-native/pull/43135) a Ã©tÃ© fusionnÃ©e qui fera de la New Arch le comportement par dÃ©faut Ã  partir de RN 0.75 (il restera possible de s'en dÃ©sactiver). De plus, l'RFC dÃ©finissant les [React Native Frameworks](https://github.com/react-native-community/discussions-and-proposals/blob/main/proposals/0759-react-native-frameworks.md) a Ã©tÃ© fusionnÃ©e, dÃ©taillant les responsabilitÃ©s de RN versus les frameworks construits dessus.

- ğŸ’¸ [React Universe Conf - join the conference at the lowest price now. Thereâ€™s a limited batch of blind bird tickets available.](https://www.reactuniverseconf.com/)
- ğŸ“œ [How to integrate Native iOS code into a React Native project for iOS](https://www.themorrow.digital/blog/how-to-integrate-native-modules-in-react-native-ios-apps): Good introduction to bridging headers, @objc, and other fun stuff you need to know before diving into native code for iOS.
- ğŸ“œ [react-strict-dom, why it's so great?](https://szymonrybczak.dev/blog/react-strict-dom) If you want to know how `<html.div>` ends up as a native component in iOS, read this short summary of react-strict-dom.

- ğŸ“œ [@expo/fingerprint ğŸ¤ GitHub Actions](https://expo.dev/blog/expo-fingerprint-github-actions): In my opinion, Fingerprint is the most underhyped feature of Expo SDK 50. This post shows the killer use case: Kicking off a new native build as soon as Fingerprint determines it is required.
- ğŸ“œ [Universal Apps: A Single, Unified Codebase Powering Mobile, Desktop, Web, and TV?](https://www.reactnativetv.com/blog/universal-apps-powering-seven-platforms) Kind of the holy grail, and a topic Iâ€™m really excited about in 2024: One app, all the platforms.
